questions.question:
Question 1: A woman with urinary incontinence was diagnosed to have a vesicovaginal fistula. What is the 
most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Vesicovaginal fistulas are mostly acquired. In developing countries, the most common cause is obstetric trauma. In developed 
countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible for 90% of the vesicovaginal 
fistulas. Congenital genitourinary fistulas and fistulas resulting from infectious conditions are rare.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following types of genitourinary fistulas has not been reported?
questions.explanation:
Uterourethral type of fistula has not been reported. A genitourinary fistula is defined as an abnormal communication between the urinary system 
(ureter, bladder, urethra) and the genital systems (vagina, cervix, uterus). Most genitourinary fistulas are acquired. In developing countries, the most common cause 
is obstetric trauma. In developed countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible 578 
Sold by @itachibot for 90% of the vesicovaginal fistulas. Congenital genitourinary fistulas are rare. If present, they are commonly associated with other 
renal or urogenital abnormalities.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following does not cause genitourinary fistulas?
questions.explanation: Hysteroscopy is not an etiology for genitourinary fistulae. It can occur following hysterectomy. Most genitourinary fistulas are acquired. Its causes are enumerated below: • Prolonged obstructed labor - major cause in developing countries • Difficult instrumental or manipulative deliveries • Injury to bladder or ureter during hysterectomy - major cause in developed contries • Congenital (rare) • Other causes include: • Radiation • Malignancy • Trauma • Infections - PID, tuberculosis etc.

questions.question:
Question 4: A P1L1 woman presents with constant dribbling of urine. She gives a history of unattended 
vaginal delivery following a difficult and prolonged labor 3 months back. What is the most 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a vesicovaginal fistula. Vesicovaginal fistulas usually present with: • Constant dribbling of urine from the vagina • Excoriation in the groin region due to constant leakage of urine • History of pelvic surgery, vaginal delivery or prolonged labor • Amenorrhea may be present On examination, the fistula may be visualized by observing urine collection in the vagina. 
Bimanual examination reveals its fixity and extent. Note: Ureterovaginal fistulas usually occur following accidental ureteric injury during C-sections 
in developing countries.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most useful test in vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.explanation:
Cystoscopy is the most useful test and also the investigation of choice for vesicovaginal fistula 
(VVF). 579 
Sold by @itachibot Cystoscopy or cystourethroscopy helps to visualize the size of the fistulas, the exact location of 
multiple fistulas and their proximity to the ureteral orifice. It can also assess the bladder mucosa 
for any injuries. The 3-swab test (Option B) is done to identify the types of genitourinary fistula. In this test, three sterile pieces of cotton swabs are serially placed in the vaginal cavity, while 
50-100ml of methylene blue solution is instilled in the bladder using a catheter. The cotton swabs 
are placed one at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. Interpretation: • Uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, as seen in ureterovaginal 
fistula • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, as seen in vesicovaginal fistula • Lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra,as seen in urethrovaginal fistula The below image shows the 3-swab test. Option C: MRI is usually not needed for the diagnosis of VVF. They can be used to study 
vesicouterine fistulas. Option D: Cystometry is done to measure the capacity of the bladder. It is used to investigate urge 
incontinence.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient comes with a complaint of dribbling of urine from the vagina during micturition. 
She has a history of obstructed labor. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done, and the lowest 
swab gets stained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a urethrovaginal fistula. Urethrovaginal fistulas have the following clinical features: • Continent and dry at rest • Urinary dribbling during micturition 580 
Sold by @itachibot • Fistulous opening is seen on per speculum examination In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. 
The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, 
and one just above the introitus. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the 
bladder using a catheter. Interpretation: • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen 
in ureterovaginal fistula • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 40-year-old woman with a history of colporrhaphy is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. 
Which of the following investigations is not preferred in this patient?
questions.explanation:
MRI is not preferred for a case of vesicovaginal fistula as other investigations are more specific 
and useful. Investigations in VVF include: • Urine culture - to treat concurrent UTI. • Ultrasound abdomen - kidney, bladder and ureter should be observed for the presence of a 
urinoma or hydronephrosis. • Intravenous pyelography - to look for hydronephrosis • Cystoscopy - used to visualise the number of fistulae and their location. Methylene blue 3-swab test in urinary fistulae - A catheter is introduced into the bladder through 
the urethra and 50-100ml methylene blue is injected. The vaginal cavity is packed with three 
sterile cotton swabs. It is interpreted as follows: 581 
Sold by @itachibot • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen 
in ureterovaginal fistula. • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula. • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula. The given image shows the methylene blue 3-swab test.

questions.question:
Question 8: 572 
Sold by @itachibot A 40-year-old woman came for a follow-up visit one week following a vaginal hysterectomy. 
You note she has developed a large vesicovaginal fistula. What is the best time for fistula 
repair in this case?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the best time to perform fistula repair is 6 weeks after the inciting surgery. In uncomplicated fistulas, early surgical intervention is preferred within the first 24 to 48 hours 
following the inciting surgery. This avoids the brisk postoperative inflammatory response. However, if extensive and severe inflammation is present, repair of fistula can be delayed to 6 
weeks after the surgery. This is usually done in a patient who has undergone major surgery, During this delay it is ensured that all the tissue inflammation has subsided, tissue vascularisation 
has improved and local infection has cleared. Estrogen therapy should be instituted in 
postmenopausal women in this time period. In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 34-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of blood in her urine. She informs 
you that this happens every month for 1 week and stops on its own. She underwent a 
C-section 1 year ago and has no history of incontinence. During clinical examination, a 
catheter is inserted into the bladder, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the catheter emerging from the cervical os. This, along with the history of 
cyclical hematuria, is suggestive of Youssef syndrome seen in a case of vesicouterine fistula. Vesicouterine fistulas can develop after cesarean section, uterine rupture, and placenta accreta. 
Most cases present weeks to years later. 582 
Sold by @itachibot Vesicouterine fistulas can present with cyclical hematuria, urinary incontinence or complete 
continence, menstrual abnormalities, and urinary tract infections. Youssef syndrome is seen in 
cases of vesicouterine fistulas, and it is associated with a classic triad: • Amenorrhea • Cyclical hematuria - also called menouria: Menstrual blood trickles into the bladder through the 
fistula, causing hematuria • Urinary continence (there is no vaginal leakage of urine) Hysteroscopy and cystoscopy are gold-standard investigations. Vesicouterine fistulas are treated as follows: • Prolonged bladder catheterization - leads to spontaneous closure • Surgical repair via abdominal route

questions.question:
Question 10: 573 
Sold by @itachibot Intravenous pyelography in a patient suspected to have a genitourinary fistula revealed a 
ureteric fistula. Which of the following is false about this condition?

options.a: It is mostly caused by gynecological surgeries
options.b: Continuous dribbling of urine occurs, but the patient can also micturate
options.c: In 3-swab test, the swab is stained blue
options.d: Hydronephrosis is present on the affected side

questions.explanation:
Swabs stained with methylene blue are obtained in a bladder fistula and not in a ureteric fistula. Ureteric fistulas can present with the following features: • Constant urinary dribbling • Flank pain or loin tenderness • Renal angle tenderness • Fever • Hematuria • Oliguria Ureteric fistulas are most commonly caused by iatrogenic trauma during pelvic surgeries, 
especially gynecological surgeries. An excretory urogram (intravenous pyelography) or a CT 
urogram are the investigations of choice. Hydronephrosis may be present on the affected side. It is managed by performing a ureteroneocystostomy and percutaneous nephrostomy.

questions.question:
Question 11: You need to locate the ureter while performing an abdominal hysterectomy. Which of the 
following features will help you identify it?
questions.explanation:
The ureter is identified intraoperatively by the following features: • Ovarian artery crosses anterior to it • It is cord-like on palpation • Peristalsis occurs on palpation • It has a pale, glistening appearance • Uterine artery crosses it, from lateral to medial, 2 cm lateral to the cervix 583 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: During post-op rounds, you note one of the patients has developed fever and flank pain. The 
nurses inform you that her abdominal drain outputs have been consistently high. Which of 
the following procedures has the highest incidence of the complication suspected here?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of ureteric injury. The highest incidence of this complication 
is seen with Wertheim’s hysterectomy. Urinary tract injury occurs almost exclusively in major gynecologic surgery that involves surgical 
dissection in proximity to the ureters or bladder. Vaginal hysterectomy tends to have lower rates 
of ureteric injuries than open (abdominal, Wertheim) or laparoscopic routes. The highest risk 
for ureteric injury is associated with the following procedures: • Surgical debulking of gynecological cancers • Advanced pelvic reconstructive surgery • Laparoscopic hysterectomy Patients with ureteric injuries have a complicated post-operative period. They can present with 
the following features: • Fever • Flank pain • Abdominal distension • Prolonged paralytic ileus - bowel sounds are absent • High drain outputs, in case abdominal drains are placed. CT urogram and retrograde pyelography are the investigations of choice. They reveal urinary 
extravasation from the ureter. Ureteric injuries are prevented by careful division of tissue planes 
during pelvic or genitourinary surgeries. The condition is managed by prompt surgical repair by 
ureteroureterostomy or percutaneous ureterostomy. 584 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with uterine fibroids is set to undergo a hysterectomy. While obtaining informed 
consent for the procedure, you counsel her about the potential risk of ureteric injury. Which 
of the following sites is the injury least likely to occur at?
questions.explanation:
Iatrogenic injury to the ureter is unlikely to occur at the ureteropelvic junction during 
gynaecological surgeries like a hysterectomy. Ureteric injury is most commonly caused by gynecological surgeries such as laparoscopic 
hysterectomy, abdominal hysterectomy, etc. It can occur at: • The infundibulopelvic ligament on the lateral pelvic wall • In the ureteric canal when the uterine vessels are ligated • Near the internal cervical os • Near the uterosacral ligament

questions.question: Question 14: What is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula?
questions.explanation:
Improper suturing of complete perineal tears is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula. Rectovaginal fistulas occur most commonly due to obstetric causes such as perineal tears, 
obstructed labor, and instrumental deliveries. Other causes include: • Tuberculosis • Lymphogranuloma venerum • Bartholinitis - rupture of an abscess into the rectum can cause a fistula • Diverticulitis • Carcinoma cervix • Radiotherapy - can cause ulceration which can develop into a fistula

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a prerequisite for maintaining female urinary continence?

options.a: Normal urethral closure pressure more than 20 cm of water
options.c: Internal urinary sphincter must lie above levator ani
options.d: Innervation of internal sphincter by Onuf's nucleus

questions.explanation: The external urinary sphincter is innervated by the Onuf's nucleus, but not the internal one. The following factors are prerequisites for continence in women: • Position of internal urinary sphincter lies above levator ani muscles • Normal urethral closure pressure is >20 cm of water • Urethrovesical angle >100 • The tone of pelvic floor muscles

questions.question:
Question 16: An elderly woman presented with a mass per vaginum and incontinence. She complains that 
she has to push the mass inwards to be able to urinate normally. What is the type of 
incontinence seen here?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocele in a case of genital prolapse. Stress 
incontinence is seen in these cases. 585 
Sold by @itachibot In stress incontinence, involuntary leakage of urine occurs when there is increased 
intraabdominal pressure, such as during laughing, sneezing, or coughing. There is no normal urge 
to pass urine. Option A: Urge incontinence is the involuntary voiding of urine when there is an imminent urge 
to urinate. Option C: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, 
with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge 
incontinence. Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs due to defects anywhere in the pathway of the micturition 
reflex, e.g., spinal cord trauma, diabetes etc. It presents with with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.question:
Question 17: A gynecologist performs a Marshall and Bonney test in the OPD on an elderly woman. Which 
of the following conditions is this used to diagnose?
questions.explanation:
Marshall and Bonney's test is used to diagnose genuine stress incontinence. It also helps in 
assessing how successful a surgical repair will be. It is performed as follows: Test 
Marshall test 
Bonney's test Procedure 
The vagina in the region of th 
e bladder neck is infiltrated 
with local anesthetic and it is 
elevated. Two fingers are placed in the 
vagina at the urethrovesical j 
unction and the bladder neck 
is elevated. Absence of leakage of urine o 
n straining or coughing Absence of leakage of urine o 
n straining or coughing Positive tes 
t

questions.question:
Question 18: A wrestler in the post-partum period complains of spurting of urine during weight-lifting 
practice. Which of the following investigations will help aid your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. It can be diagnosed with the help of 
the Q-tip test. This test is performed by placing a xylocaine-covered Q-tip cotton swab stick in the patient's 
urethra. Initially, the stick will be parallel to the floor. Then the patient is asked to strain or 
cough. Normally the stick will reach an angle of around 10-15°. In genuine stress incontinence (GSI), this angle increases by 20° or more. A positive test indicates 
a sufficient degree of bladder neck descent. Unfortunately, all patients with GSI may not have a 
positive test, and it is not specific. Tests done for GSI(Genuine stress incontinence) include: • Stress test • Cotton swab stick test • Marshall and Bonney test 586 
Sold by @itachibot • Urethroscopy • Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry etc

questions.question:
Question 19: A young mother presented with dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. Marshall and 
Bonney's test was positive. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. In this case, the first line of treatment is 
conservative management. Stress incontinence is managed as follows: Conservative management: • It is the first line of treatment. • It includes: • Kegel pelvic floor exercises for 4–6 months • Electric/magnetic stimulation for nerve damage, magnetic stimulation • Artificial urinary sphincter in neurological condition • Vaginal cones • It is also done in case surgery fails. Medical management: • Estrogen cream in menopausal woman • Venlafaxine 75 mg daily • Imipramine 10–20 mg BD Surgical management: • Kelly's repair - vaginal approach • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It not done anymore as it causes 
osteitis of the pubis. • Burch colposuspension • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation • Slings • Tension-free vaginal taping • Transobturator taping • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck • Periurethral collagen injection Vaginal sling operations have the highest long term cure rate in cases of GSI (genuine stress 
incontinence). Their long term cure rate is more than 90%. 587 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A 24-year-old primiparous woman with Grade 2 genuine stress incontinence did not respond 
to conservative management. Which of the following surgeries will not be beneficial for her 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Latzko procedure is not beneficial for a patient with genuine stress incontinence as it is done for 
vesicovaginal fistula. The various surgeries done for genuine stress incontinence (GSI) are as follows: • Vaginal approach • Kelly repair • Pacey repair • Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It is not done anymore as it causes 
osteitis of the pubis. • Burch colposuspension • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation • Slings • Tension-free vaginal taping • Transobturator taping • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck • Periurethral collagen injection

questions.question:
Question 21: 576 
Sold by @itachibot A 62-year-old woman presented with complaints of urinary urgency followed by involuntary 
escape of urine. What is the etiology of the condition she's likely suffering from?

options.a: Pelvic mass in pouch of Douglas

questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of urge incontinence. It occurs due to detrusor instability. During normal micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts after being stimulated by the 
parasympathetic nerves. In detrusor instability, detrusor muscle contracts spontaneously or on 
provocation during filling of the bladder. It is often caused by overactivity of parasympathetic 
nerves. It is usually seen in older women and is caused by: • Decreased bladder capacity - due to fibrosis • Decreased sensation • Central nervous system (CNS) inhibition - due to stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord 
involvement etc. It is associated with the following symptoms: • Incontinence • Urge to urinate • Increased frequency • Nocturia • Urination during sexual intercourse and with the sound of water, hand-washing. 588 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following patients with urinary incontinence will not have detrusor instability?
questions.explanation:
In patient 3, detrusor instability is not seen, as this is a case of functional incontinence. During normal micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts after being stimulated by the 
parasympathetic nerves. In detrusor instability, detrusor muscle contracts spontaneously or on 
provocation during filling of the bladder. It is often caused by the overactivity of parasympathetic 
nerves. It is seen usually in older women and is caused by: • Decreased bladder capacity - due to fibrosis • Decreased sensation • Central nervous system (CNS) inhibition - due to stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord 
involvement etc. It is associated with the following symptoms: • Incontinence • Urge to urinate • Increased frequency • Nocturia • Urination during sexual intercourse and with the sound of water, hand-washing. Treatment is initially conservative and include decreasing caffeine intake, smoking cessation, fluid 
restriction and weight reduction. Anticholinergic drugs and bladder training may also be tried. Note: Functional incontinence occurs in patients with disabilities, whose bladder movements are 
normal. However, due to environmental or physical barriers, involuntary leakage of urine occurs.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman presents to the ER with hypotension, tachycardia, and severe 
abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable in the abdomen. USG abdomen 
revealed a large uterine wall defect. What's the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. The most common cause is scar 
dehiscence due to a previous cesarean section. This can occur due to trial of labour after C-section, 
or due to spontaneous labor in a patient with previous C-section. Other causes of uterine rupture 
are: • Prolonged induction or augmentation of labor • Obstructed labor • Blunt abdominal trauma during pregnancy • Rupture of hematometra • Rupture of pyometra Uterine rupture is managed as follows: • Immediate cesarean section • Depending upon the extent of rupture: • Subtotal hysterectomy 589 
Sold by @itachibot • Hysterectomy 590 
Sold by @itachibot Prolapse
